title: GM laying off 500 workers at compact car plant
text:
Contractors look over a robotic assembly at the Orion Assembly in Orion Township, Mich., (Photo: Carlos Osorio, AP) 
3 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE DETROIT -- General Motors will suspend a second production shift in January at its Orion assembly plant in Michigan and lay off about 500 workers.
They make the Chevrolet Sonic and Buick Verano subcompacts which are not selling well as Americans migrate toward large pickup trucks, SUVs and crossover models. Verano sales fell 27% through the first nine months of 2016 from a year earlier. Sonic sales have fallen 35% in the same period.
Last June, the company said it would invest $245 million and hire 300 people at Orion Assembly to build the new Chevrolet Bolt electric car beginning next year, and an unnamed future model.
"Orion Assembly is a breeding ground for manufacturing innovation," Cathy Clegg, GM vice president of North America manufacturing and labor relations said at the time. "It serves as a model for how to engage the entire workforce at all levels to achieve success."
Most of the 500 workers laid off at the Orion plant will have the opportunity to move to GM's Detroit-Hamtramck plant where the automaker said Thursday it will add a second shift as it ramps up production of the second-generation Chevrolet Volt, the Cadillac CT6 and possibly the Buick LaCrosse sometime next year.
"We are confident we will be able to make transfer offers to Detroit-Hamtramck or other GM locations for the vast majority of those who are affected by the shift reduction," the company said in a statement.
Under a special agreement with the UAW, GM was able to run the Orion Township plant with up to 40% of the work force filled with lower-paid workers.
The moves at the two assembly plants come as the UAW moves to negotiate a new labor agreement with GM after workers at Fiat Chrysler ratified their contract earlier this week.
The union represents about 52,700 hourly workers at GM plants throughout the U.S.
